dt.t: had no {wi}acquaintance{/wi} with the facts of the case

dt: {bc}a person whom one knows but who is not a particularly close friend

quotes.t: But all those qualities are so wrapped up in others that one could hardly ask for two men who are, at first {qword}acquaintance{/qword}, more different.
But Francis later found out that the dinner {qword}acquaintance{/qword} who sweet-talked him got a thank-you check for three thousand pounds.

A classical education, or at any rate a very extensive {qword}acquaintance{/qword} with English literature, ancient and modern, appears to me quite indispensable for the person who would do any just to your clergyman; and I think I may boast myself to be, with all possible vanity, the most unlearned and uninformed female who ever dared to be an authoress.

et: Middle English {it}acointance, aqueyntaunce,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}acointance, aqueyntance,{/it} from {it}acointer{/it} "to {et_link|acquaint|acquaint}" + {it}-ance{/it} {et_link|-ance|-ance}
shortdef: the persons with whom one is acquainted

dt: {bc}rape committed by someone known to the victim

shortdef: rape committed by someone known to the victim

dt: {bc}a small amount of knowledge about someone or something

dt.t: We only have a {it}nodding acquaintance{/it} with each other.
I only have a {it}nodding acquaintance{/it} with Greek history.

shortdef: a small amount of knowledge about someone or something

dt.t: It's a pleasure to {it}make your acquaintance{/it}.
She {it}made the acquaintance of{/it} a man from the city.

meta.id: more than a passing acquaintance with
stems: more than a passing acquaintance with

hwi.hw: more than a passing acquaintance with

dt.t: He has {it}more than a passing acquaintance with{/it} wine.
He seemed cold {it}on/at first acquaintance{/it}, but later I realized that he was just shy.
